column5: risk_factor:"Factors that put you at greater risk of developing dengue fever or a more severe form of the disease include:\n\nLiving or traveling in tropical areas. Being in tropical and subtropical areas increases your risk of exposure to the virus that causes dengue fever. Especially high-risk areas are Southeast Asia
column7: Latin America and the Caribbean.\nPrior infection with a dengue fever virus. Previous infection with a dengue fever virus increases your risk of having severe symptoms if you're infected again."
column8: cause:"Dengue fever is caused by any one of four types of dengue viruses spread by mosquitoes that thrive in and near human lodgings. When a mosquito bites a person infected with a dengue virus
column9: the virus enters the mosquito. When the infected mosquito then bites another person
column10: the virus enters that person's bloodstream.\n\nAfter you've recovered from dengue fever
column11: you have immunity to the type of virus that infected you â€” but not to the other three dengue fever virus types. The risk of developing severe dengue fever
column12: also known as dengue hemorrhagic fever
column13: actually increases if you're infected a second
column15: treatment:"If you have severe dengue fever
column16:
you may need:

Supportive care in a hospital
Intravenous (IV) fluid and electrolyte replacement
Blood pressure monitoring
Transfusion to replace blood loss"
column20:
is currently approved for use in those ages 9 to 45 who live in areas with a high incidence of dengue fever. The vaccine is given in three doses over the course of 12 months. Dengvaxia prevents dengue infections slightly more than half the time.

The vaccine is approved only for older children because younger vaccinated children appear to be at increased risk of severe dengue fever and hospitalization two years after receiving the vaccine.

The World Health Organization stresses that the vaccine is not an effective tool
column22: to reduce dengue fever in areas where the illness is common. Controlling the mosquito population and human exposure is still the most critical part of prevention efforts.\n\nSo for now
column23: if you're living or traveling in an area where dengue fever is known to be
column24: the best way to avoid dengue fever is to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes that carry the disease."

column36: info:"A doctor can diagnose dengue fever by performing a blood test. The test will show whether the blood sample contains dengue virus or antibodies to the virus."
